qas.question: When did Bermuda have a large amount of people immigrating to it?

answers.text: 20th century, especially after the Second World War.

qas.question: Where are the largest group of non-native people in Bermuda from?
According to census result, there was the greatest decline in people claiming what ancestry?
Which cultural group can claim 79% residency?
During what century was the diverse immigration?
What did 46% of the population identify as in 2000?
What did 51% of the population identify as in 2010?

plausible_answers.text: people born in the West Indies

qas.question: What group of people increased by 583?

context: The island experienced large-scale immigration over the <a0_0><b4_0>20th century<b4_0/>, especially after the Second World War.<a0_0/> Bermuda has a diverse population including both those with relatively deep roots in Bermuda extending back for centuries, and newer communities whose ancestry results from recent immigration, especially from Britain, North America, the West Indies, and the Portuguese Atlantic islands (especially the Azores), although these groups are steadily merging. About 46% of the population identified themselves with <a2_0><b5_0><b6_0>Bermudian<a2_0/> ancestry<b6_0/><b5_0/> in 2010, which was a decrease from the 51% who did so in the 2000 census. Those identifying with British ancestry dropped by 1% to 11% (although <b7_0>those born in <a1_0>Britain<b7_0/><a1_0/> remain the largest non-native group at 3,942 persons). The number of people born in Canada declined by 13%. Those who reported West Indian ancestry were 13%. The number of <b8_0>people born in the West Indies<b8_0/> actually increased by 538. A significant segment of the population is of <a3_0>Portuguese<a3_0/> ancestry (10%), the result of immigration over the past 160 years, of whom 79% have residency status.
